1.title: Adding CSS and JS¶
1.body: Your components might need custom styles or custom JavaScript for many reasons. Instead of using global stylesheet or scripts files, writing assets per individual component has several advantages:
1.raw: Your components might need custom styles or custom JavaScript for many reasons Instead of using global stylesheet or scripts files writing assets per individual component has several advantages

2.title: Adding CSS and JS¶
2.body:
• Portability: You can copy a component from one project to another kmowing it will keep working as expected.
  • Performance: On each page, only load the css and js that you need. Also, the browser will already have cached the assets of the components for other pages that use them.
  • Simple testing: You can test the JS of a component indepently from others.
2.raw: Portability You can copy a component from one project to another kmowing it will keep working as expected Performance On each page only load the css and js that you need Also the browser will already have cached the assets of the components for other pages that use them Simple testing You can test the JS of a component indepently from others

3.title: Declaring assets¶
3.body: The css and/or the js of a component must be declared in the metatada header with {#css ... #} and {#js ... #}
3.raw: The css and/or the js of a component must be declared in the metatada header with {#css ... #} and {#js ... #}

5.title: Declaring assets¶
5.body: The filepaths must be relative to the root of your components catalog (e.g.: components/). Both of these list are optional.
5.raw: The filepaths must be relative to the root of your components catalog e.g. components/ Both of these list are optional

6.title: Including assets in your pages¶
6.body: The catalog will collect all css and js file paths from the components used on a "page" render on the catalog.collected_css and catalog.collected_js lists.
6.raw: The catalog will collect all css and js file paths from the components used on a page render on the catalog.collected_css and catalog.collected_js lists

7.title: Including assets in your pages¶
7.raw: For example after rendering this component

9.title: Including assets in your pages¶
9.body:
{#css mypage.css #}
{#js mypage.js #}

<Layout title="My page">
  <Card>
    <CardBody>
      <h1>Lizard</h1>
      <p>The Iguana is a type of lizard</p>
    </CardBody>
    <CardActions>
      <Button size="small">Share</Button>
    </CardActions>
  </Card>
</Layout>
9.raw:
{#css mypage.css #} {#js mypage.js #}

Lizard

The Iguana is a type of lizard

10.title: Including assets in your pages¶
10.body: Asuming the Card, and Button components declare css assests, this will the state of the collected_css list:
10.raw: Asuming the Card and Button components declare css assests this will the state of the collected_css list

12.title: Including assets in your pages¶
12.body: You can add the <link> and <script> tags in your page automatically by rendering the global components_assets variable in your layout component like this:
12.raw: You can add the <link> and <script> tags in your page automatically by rendering the global components_assets variable in your layout component like this

14.title: Including assets in your pages¶
14.body:
{#def title #}

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8">
  <title>{{ title }}</title>
  {{ components_assets }}
</head>
<body>
  {{ content }}
</body>
</html>
14.raw: {#def title #} <!DOCTYPE html> <html lang="en"> <head> <meta charset="utf-8"> <title>{{ title }}</title> {{ components_assets }} </head> <body> {{ content }} </body> </html>

15.title: Including assets in your pages¶
15.raw: The variable will be rendered as

16.title: Including assets in your pages¶
16.body:
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/static/components/mypage.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/static/components/card.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/static/components/button.css">
<script src="/static/components/mypage.js" defer></script>
<script src="/static/components/card.js" defer></script>
<script src="/static/components/button.js" defer></script>
16.raw: <link rel="stylesheet" href="/static/components/mypage.css"> <link rel="stylesheet" href="/static/components/card.css"> <link rel="stylesheet" href="/static/components/button.css"> <script src="/static/components/mypage.js" defer></script> <script src="/static/components/card.js" defer></script> <script src="/static/components/button.js" defer></script>

17.title: Middleware¶
17.body: The tags above will not work at all if your application can't return the content of those files, and right now it can't.
17.raw: The tags above will not work at all if your application can t return the content of those files and right now it can t

18.title: Middleware¶
18.body: For that reason, JinjaX include a WSGI middleware that will process those URLs if you add it to your application.
18.raw: For that reason JinjaX include a WSGI middleware that will process those URLs if you add it to your application

19.title: Middleware¶
19.body:
from flask import Flask
from jinjax import Catalog

app = Flask(__name__)

# Here we add the flask Jinja globals, filters, etc.
# like `url_for()`
catalog = jinjax.Catalog(
    globals=app.jinja_env.globals,
    filters=app.jinja_env.filters,
    tests=app.jinja_env.tests,
    extensions=app.jinja_env.extensions,
)
catalog.add_folder("myapp/components")

app.wsgi_app = catalog.get_middleware(
    app.wsgi_app,
    autorefresh=app.debug,
)
19.raw: from flask import Flask from jinjax import Catalog app = Flask(__name__) # Here we add the flask Jinja globals, filters, etc. # like `url_for()` catalog = jinjax.Catalog( globals=app.jinja_env.globals, filters=app.jinja_env.filters, tests=app.jinja_env.tests, extensions=app.jinja_env.extensions, ) catalog.add_folder("myapp/components") app.wsgi_app = catalog.get_middleware( app.wsgi_app, autorefresh=app.debug, )

20.title: Middleware¶
20.body: The middleware uses the battle-tested Whitenoise library and it will only respond to the .css and .js files inside the component(s) folder(s). You can configure it to also return files with other extensions. For example:
20.raw: The middleware uses the battle-tested Whitenoise library and it will only respond to the css and js files inside the component s folder s You can configure it to also return files with other extensions For example

22.title: Middleware¶
22.body: Be aware that, if you use this option, get_middleware() must be called after all foldes are added.
22.raw: Be aware that if you use this option get_middleware() must be called after all foldes are added

23.title: CSS Scoping¶
23.body:
...

The styles of your components will not be auto-scoped. This means the styles of a component can affect other components, and, likewise, it will be affected by global styles or the styles of other components.
23.raw: The styles of your components will not be auto-scoped This means the styles of a component can affect other components and likewise it will be affected by global styles or the styles of other components

24.title: CSS Scoping¶
24.body: To protect yourself against that, always add a custom class to the root element(s) of your component and use it to scope the rest of the component styles. Example:
24.raw: To protect yourself against that always add a custom class to the root element s of your component and use it to scope the rest of the component styles Example

28.title: CSS Scoping¶
28.body:
/* 🚫 DO NOT do this */
h1 { font-size: 2em; }
h2 { font-size: 1.5em; }
a { color: blue; }

/* 👍 DO THIS instead */
.Card h1 { font-size: 2em; }
.Card h2 { font-size: 1.5em; }
.Card a { color: blue; }
28.raw: /* 🚫 DO NOT do this */ h1 { font-size: 2em; } h2 { font-size: 1.5em; } a { color: blue; } /* 👍 DO THIS instead */ .Card h1 { font-size: 2em; } .Card h2 { font-size: 1.5em; } .Card a { color: blue; }

29.title: CSS Scoping¶
29.body: Always use a class instead of an id, or the component will not be usable more than once per page.
29.raw: Always use a class instead of an id or the component will not be usable more than once per page

30.title: JS events¶
30.body: Your components might be inserted in the page on-the fly, after the JavaScript files has been loaded and executed. So, attaching events to the elements on the page on load will not be enough:
30.raw: Your components might be inserted in the page on-the fly after the JavaScript files has been loaded and executed So attaching events to the elements on the page on load will not be enough

32.title: JS events¶
32.body:
// This will fail for any Card component inserted after page load
document.querySelectorAll('.Card button.share')
  .forEach( (node) => {
    node.addEventListener("click", handleClick)
  })

/* ... etc ... */
32.raw: // This will fail for any Card component inserted after page load document.querySelectorAll('.Card button.share') .forEach( (node) => { node.addEventListener("click", handleClick) }) /* ... etc ... */

33.title: JS events¶
33.body: A solution can be using the MutationObserver JS API to detect changes to the document and attach the events to all the new inserted components:
33.raw: A solution can be using the MutationObserver JS API to detect changes to the document and attach the events to all the new inserted components

35.title: JS events¶
35.body:
new MutationObserver( (mutationList) => {
  mutationList.forEach( (mutation) => {
    if (mutation.type !== "childList") return
    mutation.addedNodes.forEach( (node) => {
      if (node.nodeType === 1) {
        addEvents(node)
      }
    })
  })
})
.observe(document.body, {
    subtree: true,
    childList: true,
    attributes: false,
    characterData: false
})

function addEvents (root) {
  /* Attach events to all the child components
  of the new node */
  root.querySelectorAll('.Card button.share')
    .forEach( (node) => {
      node.addEventListener("click", handleClick)
    })
}

// We call it a first time to attach the events for the
// components present on the document on page load
addEvents(document)

/* ... etc ... */
35.raw: new MutationObserver( (mutationList) => { mutationList.forEach( (mutation) => { if (mutation.type !== "childList") return mutation.addedNodes.forEach( (node) => { if (node.nodeType === 1) { addEvents(node) } }) }) }) .observe(document.body, { subtree: true, childList: true, attributes: false, characterData: false }) function addEvents (root) { /* Attach events to all the child components of the new node */ root.querySelectorAll('.Card button.share') .forEach( (node) => { node.addEventListener("click", handleClick) }) } // We call it a first time to attach the events for the // components present on the document on page load addEvents(document) /* ... etc ... */
